title: Invisible vs Idle Status: Simple Ways to Change Your Discord Status

steps.title: Idle.
steps.content: Idle. Instead of a green dot, you'll see a yellow half-moon icon. This applies automatically if you haven't interacted with Discord within the last 5 minutes, but still have the app open. The Idle indicator is similar to typing "AFK" in the chat – Away From Keyboard. It's a signal that the user most likely isn't currently using Discord.

steps.title: Online.
steps.content: Online. This displays as a green dot or a green outline of a phone if you're only using Discord on your phone. It's usually the default status for Discord when you're using the app. A green dot (or green phone icon [1] X Research source ) means that you're actively on Discord, which can be either making a phone call, in a voice or video chat, or moving your mouse around Discord. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Do Not Disturb.
steps.content: Do Not Disturb. Anyone with a red dot that has a line through it most likely does not want to be bothered, but they don't want to close the app. You'll want to use this if you're annoyed by the Discord notifications but want to keep the app open.

steps.title: Offline/Invisible.
steps.content: Offline/Invisible. Indicated with an empty circle that has a thick circle outline, this is usually applied automatically to users that close the app. However, you can enable it manually so you can have the app open, but appear as though you're offline to others.

steps.title: Streaming.
steps.content: Streaming. When you're streaming, Discord is open and connected to the streaming service you're using, you'll see a purple circle next to your profile instead of a green dot. To get this purple dot, you'll need to enable Streaming Mode in User Settings > Streamer Mode and connect Discord to a streaming account in User Settings > Connections . Finally, enable Discord to show your activity in "User Settings > Account Privacy > Display Current activity as a status message" and start streaming!

steps.title: Open Discord.
steps.content: Open Discord. Tap the app icon that looks like a controller on a light blue background. This method will walk you through the process of changing your status on Discord using the mobile app on Android and iOS.

steps.title: Tap your profile picture.
steps.content: Tap your profile picture. If you're instead looking at a channel, swipe your finger from the left to the right on your screen to pull open the side menu.

steps.title: Tap Set Status and pick one.
steps.content: Tap Set Status and pick one. Tap one to use and it will apply immediately to your profile. [3] X Research source You can choose Online, Idle, Do Not Disturb, and Invisible. Click Set a custom status to use one of the above with a custom message. Give it a name, an optional emoji, and choose a status, like Online or Invisible. Choose when you want the custom status to disappear and click Save .

steps.title: Open Discord.
steps.content: Open Discord. Click the app icon that looks like a controller on a light blue background. This method walks you through changing your Discord status using the desktop client on Windows and Mac.

steps.title: Click your profile picture.
steps.content: Click your profile picture. It's in the lower-left corner of the Discord window. If you want to set a custom status, click Set Custom Status . Title your custom status, maybe give it an emoji, decide if you want the status to clear automatically, and click Save . [4] X Research source

steps.title: Hover your mouse over your current status and select a new one.
steps.content: Hover your mouse over your current status and select a new one. Once you do this, your status will change immediately. You can choose Online, Idle, Do Not Disturb, and Invisible.

steps.title: "Idle" isn't the only internet slang—there are plenty others!
steps.content: "Idle" isn't the only internet slang—there are plenty others! Are the following terms in your virtual lexicon? CFS : Close Friends Story on Instagram FFF : "follow for follow" IDM : "I don't mind" ISK : "I should know" or a typo for "IDK" ("I don't know") LF : gaming shorthand for “looking for” MCM : "man crush Monday" Mmk : a combination of "mmhmm" and "OK," used to express disinterest or irritation, or just as a softer, more casual version of "OK" MBN : "must be nice" OOMF : "one of my followers" or "one of my friends" OMW : "on my way" PMO : "put me on," as in, "introduce to someone/something" WSP : "What's up?" WCW : "woman crush Wednesday" YW : "You're welcome"
